item.title: [317 - Delta] Skillcape Trimming!
item.dc:creator: @_ZeroScape `ZeroScape
item.description:
@_ZeroScape wrote:

If you have a skillcape worn, and have more than one 99 skill, then yes, it trims.
But this code also have an untrimmer included, so wearing trimmed cape with only one 99 skill will make your cape untrimmed.

item.title: [317 - Delta] Skillcape Trimming!
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

It’s good to see more and more people using arrays now. However, you can use the enhanced for-loop for most things in this tutorial; for example, you can shorten down your “MaxedSkills()” method to:

public int MaxedSkills() { int maxedSklls = 0; for (int level : playerLevel) { if (level >= 99) { maxedSkills++; } } return maxedSklls; }

Read full topic

item.title: [317 - Delta] Skillcape Trimming!
item.dc:creator: @_ZeroScape `ZeroScape
item.description:
@_ZeroScape wrote:

Tutorial on: Adding skillcape trimming.
Class modified: Client.java
Difficulty: 3 of 10.

Step 1!
Under the public class client extends Player implements Runnable { add this integer array:

[code=java] public int Skillcape[] = { // Contains all untrimmed skillcape id’s.
2677, 2683, 2680, 2701, 2686, 2689, 2692,
2731, 2734, 2716, 2728, 2695, 2713, 2725,
2722, 2707, 2704, 2710, 2719, 2737, 2698
};

public int SkillcapeT[] = { // Contains all trimmed skillcape id's.
	4319, 4329, 4359, 4341, 4351, 4347, 4343,
	4325, 4353, 4337, 4335, 4321, 4327, 4357,
	4345, 4339, 4317, 4361, 4355, 4331, 4333
};[/code][b][/b]

Step 2!
Under that add this method:

private void SkillcapeTrim() { /** * This will check if trimming is required! */ for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) { if ((playerEquipment[playerCape] == Skillcape[i]) && (MaxedSkills() >= 2)) { playerEquipment[playerCape] = SkillcapeT[i]; playerEquipmentN[playerCape] = 1; setEquipment(SkillcapeT[i], 1, playerCape); updateRequired = true; appearanceUpdateRequired = true; } } /** * This will check if untrimming is required. */ for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) { if ((playerEquipment[playerCape] == SkillcapeT[i]) && (MaxedSkills() < 2)) { playerEquipment[playerCape] = Skillcape[i]; playerEquipmentN[playerCape] = 1; setEquipment(Skillcape[i], 1, playerCape); updateRequired = true; appearanceUpdateRequired = true; } } }

Step 3!
You’ll also need this:

public int MaxedSkills() { int maxedSklls = 0; for (int level : playerLevel) { if (level >= 99) { maxedSklls++; } } return maxedSklls; }

Step 4!
Under public boolean process() { add:

for (int i = 0; i < Skillcape.length; i++) { if (playerEquipment[playerCape] == Skillcape[i] || playerEquipment[playerCape] == SkillcapeT[i]) { SkillcapeTrim(); } }

Step 5!
Also add the for (int i = 0; i < Skillcape.length; i++) { if (playerEquipment[playerCape] == Skillcape[i] || playerEquipment[playerCape] == SkillcapeT[i]) { SkillcapeTrim(); } } below if (oldLevel < getLevelForXP(playerXP[skill])) {

[b]Now you have full skillcape trimming (and untrimming) on your server!
I will explain better once I have spare time. I spent too much time on my newly released Cooking base.

[size=18pt]Credits:[/size]
[100%] `ZeroScape

Before everyone start saying this have to be leeched as I released two tutorials with a small interval I want to tell you something:

  • I’ve worked on the cooking handler today - 100% credits to me.
  • This is something I made for my server months ago. Just fixed some of it now.

Also note that I’m aware this is an uncomplete tutorial - but I’ll add explanations by tomorrow (Moderators - please don’t lock).

Hope you like it and use it! Give me idea’s to improve it! I accept all ideas and will have them in main in the future.
Thanks,
`ZeroScape.

Read full topic
